@graph.reasoning: Nonprice restrictions were unlawful per se

@graph.@id: Business Electronics Corp. v. Sharp Electronics Corp.
@graph.involvedParties: Business Electronics Corp. v. Sharp Electronics Corp.
@graph.reasoning: Primary purpose of antitrust laws is to protect interbrand competition
Low prices benefit consumers regardless of how they are set

@graph.@id: Matsushita Elec. Industrial Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp.
@graph.involvedParties: Matsushita Elec. Industrial Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp.
@graph.reasoning: Cutting prices to increase business is the essence of competition
Supplier cannot squeeze dealers' margins below competitive level
Supplier may fix maximum resale price to prevent dealers from exploiting monopoly power
Ban on maximum resale price limitations has prompted many suppliers to integrate forward into distribution

@graph.@id: P. Areeda & H. Hovenkamp, Antitrust Law 729.7
@graph.caseNumber: P. Areeda & H. Hovenkamp, Antitrust Law 729.7
@graph.reasoning: Litigation between independent distributors and publishers has arisen since Albrecht

@graph.@id: Blair & Lang, Albrecht After ARCO: Maximum Resale Price Fixing Moves Toward the Rule of Reason
@graph.caseNumber: Blair & Lang, Albrecht After ARCO: Maximum Resale Price Fixing Moves Toward the Rule of Reason
@graph.reasoning: Maximum pricing may not be harmful to competition and consumers

@graph.@id: Lopatka, Stephen Breyer and Modern Antitrust: A Snug Fit
@graph.caseNumber: Lopatka, Stephen Breyer and Modern Antitrust: A Snug Fit
@graph.reasoning: Supplier unlikely to profit from limiting market by excluding potential dealers
Vertical maximum price fixing can be recognized and punished under the rule of reason
Maximum pricing may mask minimum pricing
